awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: P2C2--Interrogating the Free Troposphere during the Last Deglaciation
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to provide the first global-scale constraints on temperature and dynamics of the free- troposphere- which comprises altitudes ranging from about 2 - 18 km. Specifically, the researcher will use new isotopic measurements and 3 Dimensional (3D) global modeling to reconstruct and interpret high-altitude atmospheric temperature and circulation changes during the last deglaciation (18,000 to 8,000 years before present). This project will use an emerging tracer from ice-core records to generate a paleo-temperature record that will reveal the state of the troposphere and its interaction with the stratosphere across the most recent major climate transition in Earth history. Research goals include constraining the thermal evolution of the free troposphere during a time period that includes several episodes of abrupt climate change; testing modeled free-troposphere responses to orbital and greenhouse-gas forcing; and testing stratosphere-to- troposphere exchange dynamics across major climate transitions. This combined measurement-modeling study will constrain the paleoclimate at altitude during the most recent major episode of global change, when circulation patterns shifted under different climatic boundary conditions. 

The potential Broader Impacts include developing a new temperature record of the free troposphere during the last deglaciation. The application of a new isotopic tracer to investigate the dynamics of stratosphere-troposphere exchange is potentially transformative for paleoclimate research. Other broader impacts include participation of the researchers in STEM outreach events as part of their ongoing activities, including participation in the department’s annual Earth Day at Rice University with the Girl Scouts. The project will train one undergraduate and two graduate students, and support two early career researchers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to understand changes to free-atmospheric temperatures and oxidant chemistry in different climates. The climates studied were the last glacial maximum (LGM; ~20,000 years ago) and the last interglacial period (LIG; ~125,000 years ago), using samples of the ancient atmosphere locked in Antarctic ice cores and simulations of ancient atmospheric chemistry and dynamics. The proxy used was the abundance of the exceptionally rare 18O18O variant of atmospheric oxygen, which acts as an ancient "weather balloon" owing to its sensitivity to free-atmospheric temperatures and ozone concentrations.

The free atmosphere of the LGM was found to be 6-9°C cooler than the preindustrial period (1590-1850 CE), indicating a minorly or negligibly steeper atmospheric lapse rate (drop in temperature with altitude) during that time, This globally averaged result differs from results suggested by other, site-specific studies, highlighting the heterogeneity in atmospheric temperature changes at altitude. This result has implications for our understanding of recent high-altitude warming, and how it might change in the future. 

The LIG, which had similar or slightly warmer global temperatures than today, was found to have ~9% less tropospheric ozone than the preindustrial period. The most likely explanation of this difference in atmospheric oxidant chemistry is that it reflects less biomass burning during the LIG due to the presence of terrestrial megafauna: megafauna would have reduced grassy and woody biomass during the LIG. Subsequent megafaunal extinctions allowed this biomass to accumulate on land, leading to increased biomass burning, and ultimately increased tropospheric ozone, during the preindustrial period. This result highlights the influence of land animals, particularly herbivores, on global atmospheric chemistry. 

This grant supported the training of a graduate student and a postdoctoral scholar, as well as publications, datasets, and conference presentations that dissemenated the results to the broader community.
